Kusch, Frank M.
105 Ave. O. South, Saskatoon.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about having blank spaces. If there is a question which you cannot answer, simply leave it blank.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or reply for a separate questionnaire.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1924, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or reply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneers First: What Did They Do?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, please put a check mark here.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer settlement
- Pioneer farming experience
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of our permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaires to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who has lived in exactly the same circumstances as another can answer all questions. It is impossible for anyone to answer all questions accurately without having had personal experience. The questions are intended to give details or descriptive particulars about the pioneer experiences.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who have lived in Western Canada before 1934, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets of paper for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Board has prepared questionnaires for various purposes. If you have any questions regarding these questionnaires, please put a check mark here.

1. Pioneer Experiences
2. Pioneer Health Conditions
3. Pioneer Social Activities
4. Pioneer Recreation
5. Pioneer Education
6. Pioneer Farming Experience

after I grew up I became a jack of all

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They thought my parents were foolish to go there since there were no school churches or missions.

12. Did you travel by train, bus, or with family, friends, or other groups?

Bus.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Ox team drove a bunch of cattle for stock raising etc.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with animals, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)

The only thing that I still remember is that when traveling in a waggon, we crossed a creek then tug of Blackfoot or Blackfoot river from the waggon and none of us gave me a broken piece of tug with millet or little cow in Blackfoot river.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Blackfoot.

16. Where did you settle or take up land in Saskatchewan?

In 1879, R.S.West of 13th.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Downery area.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

After I grew up, I became a jack of all trades, Blacksmith, carpenter, blacksmith, Engineer, Electrician, Painter, Farmer, Etc.

Later done some surveying near Humboldt.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home? Never

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Marie George. Aug 28th 1906 at Prince Albert

21. Did anyone else come to Cashattawan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

Quite a lot came by my state efforts

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

Came from out and settled here

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

One man that I remember best is Geo. Horn

He was one of the first school teacher here

He also was an ordained Anglican minister

He acted as a doctor, music teacher, druggist

and an all around handy man (over)

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

I went to Prince Albert school about half the time
Marie George, Aug 28th 1906 at Purvis, Allen

Quit a lot came by my state efforts

Came from out and settled here

One man that be remembered is Geo. Horn

He was me of the first school teacher here

He also was an ordained Anglican minister

He acted as a doctor, movie teacher, druggist

and an all around handy man (over)

I went to Purvis, Allen school about half the time
I also remember in 1889 some men were talking about the railroad coming to Poveshull in fact our main road to could see the smoke of an engine some miles north of here. My brother Albert & I went out. The gang said let's go out and meet the track layer gang so out we go and met the outfit about 6 or 7 miles out. The gang wouldn't let me go home. I stayed with them till we reached here. Of course they sent my brother home to repent that he had good care.

Also the Insurance Co. really still hurt me. For a lot of abuse & reviled they gave me a few thousand hand bills to distribute on each train through here. Remember all the newspapers were saying he after reaching said Bill (below) don't forget to stop at Poveshull on the railroad center of the South Dakota Valley. They all wanted to know where all the RR were. I didn't receive any country club.
In later months in 1889, some men went talking about the railroad coming to Rockton. In fact, our man said he could see the smoke of an engine some miles south of here. "My broth, Albert," you know, said, "let's go out and meet the track layer gang, or not we go out and meet the outfit about six or seven miles out. The gang wouldn't let me go home. I stayed with them till we reached here. Of course they sent my brother home. I regret that I had good care."

Also, the Insurance Co. really still hurt me. For a lot of abuse & reward they gave me a few thousand hand bills to distribute on each train through here & remember all the passengers were robbing me after reaching said Bill (below)

Don't forget to stop at Rockton town the railroad center of the South DeKalb Valley.

They all wanted to know where all the RR were. I didn't receive our county & debt.
